problem_text:
A subgroup H of a group G is called commensurated if for all g ∈ G, the index |H : H ∩ gHg−1| is finite. Can a non-abelian free group (or a non-elementary hyperbolic group) contain two infinite commensurated subgroups A, B with a trivial intersection? The answer is negative if A or B is normal.
P.-E. Caprace
